title.narrative: Food Security emergency support for drought-affected and vulnerable households

description.narrative: The objective of this FAO project is to prevent the further deterioration of living conditions of the rural populations affected by the 2018 drought in Choluteca and El Paraiso departments, by re-establishing their food production capacity. FAO will procure and distribute 31,500 seedlings of cassava, sweet potato and pineapple, 600 basic-grain seeds kits, 600 assorted vegetable seeds kits and fertilizers, along with 918 micro-irrigation kits and 810 grain-storage bins. This 749,994 USD project will last eight months and will benefit 15,000 people including 4,746 women and 2,602 girls), to quickly restore crops and livestock production.

participating-org.narrative: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)

owner-org.narrative: UN OCHA Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF)

organisation.narrative: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

mailing-address.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF), 2 United Nations Plaza (DC2), East 44th street (13th floor), United Nations, New York, USA

description.narrative: Disbursement to CERF Project Food Security emergency support for drought-affected and vulnerable households

receiver-org.narrative: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)

title.narrative: RESIDENT / HUMANITARIAN COORDINATOR REPORT ON THE USE OF CERF FUNDS HONDURAS UNDERFUNDED EMERGENCIES DROUGHT 2019

condition.narrative: CERF funding is based on an agreed proposal, including specific planned outcomes and outputs.

description.narrative: Basic emergency livelihood assistance to the most vulnerable and food insecure families affected by drought is provided. Food Security - Agriculture (incl. livestock, fisheries and other agriculture based livelihoods)
% of families have been trained in good agricultural practices for the adequate management of their livelihoods (backyard gardens, and crops)
% of families that receive basic-grain seeds, assorted vegetable seeds and fertilizers
% of families with sustainable family gardens disaggregated by household
No. of families that have access to water harvesting infrastructure (micro irrigation kits)
NGOs and local governments have technical and methodological capabilities to provide emergency assistance.
Number of Good Agricultural Practices (GAP) promoted and implemented to reduce risk and increase resilience in the face of drought and with a gender approach.
Number of municipalities that implement local ordinances in favor of good environmental practices.
Percentage of households that implement GAP promoted and implemented in the framework of the project for risk reduction and resilience in the face of drought.
